snippet.title: Coast students drug shame: Shock figures reveal problem
snippet.content: CHILDREN as young as nine are being suspended from the region's schools for misconduct involving drugs, tobacco and alcohol. According to the Department of Education and Training in 2016 two suspensions were dolled out in the North Coast region (including the Sunshine Coast) to Year 4 students for misconduct involving illicit substances and two Year 6 students were excluded - 10 drug-related suspensions were recorded overall for primary school students. As for high school, experimental Year 8 students accounted for the majority of problems with illicit substances, racking up 55 suspensions and 10 exclusions. There have been two high-profile cases of drugs in Coast schools this year, with one incident requiring several girls be taken to hospital. In May, three Coolum State High School Year 11 and 12 students were hospitalised after taking Lyrica - a drug used to treat nerve pain and seizures - during a lunch break. One of the girls was knocked unconscious by the drug and suffered seizures. Less than a week later, four girls from Nambour State College were suspended after footage from Snapchat showed them smoking a bong on school property while in uniform. It's not just drugs that have students missing school - tobacco, alcohol and other legal substances are also a big issue. In 2016 the youngest children in the region to be suspended for misconduct involving tobacco and other legal substances were in Year 4, with four incidents recorded. Year 10 students were seemingly the problem children with 107 suspensions and one exclusion for the same reason. The next highest offenders were Year 11 students with 88 suspensions. The Queensland Department of Education and Training have been contacted to provide a break-down of misconducts in Sunshine Coast schools. This is how early you need to be at the airport now.
